title: On the Unlikelihood of D-Separation. (arXiv:2303.05628v1 [cs.LG])
abstract: Causal discovery aims to recover a causal graph from data generated by it; constraint based methods do so by searching for a d-separating conditioning set of nodes in the graph via an oracle. In this paper, we provide analytic evidence that on large graphs, d-separation is a rare phenomenon, even when guaranteed to exist, unless the graph is extremely sparse. We then provide an analytic average case analysis of the PC Algorithm for causal discovery, as well as a variant of the SGS Algorithm we call UniformSGS. We consider a set $V=\{v_1,\ldots,v_n\}$ of nodes, and generate a random DAG $G=(V,E)$ where $(v_a, v_b) \in E$ with i.i.d. probability $p_1$ if $a<b$ and $0$ if $a > b$. We provide upper bounds on the probability that a subset of $V-\{x,y\}$ d-separates $x$ and $y$, conditional on $x$ and $y$ being d-separable; our upper bounds decay exponentially fast to $0$ as $|V| \rightarrow \infty$.
